blocks.name: coprimeprodsq
blocks.content: If three numbers are coprime, and the square of one is the product of the other two, then there is a formula for the other two in terms of ` gcd ` and square. (Contributed by Scott Fenton, 2-Apr-2014.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 19-Apr-2014.)

blocks.name: coprimeprodsq2
blocks.content: If three numbers are coprime, and the square of one is the product of the other two, then there is a formula for the other two in terms of ` gcd ` and square. (Contributed by Scott Fenton, 17-Apr-2014.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 19-Apr-2014.)

thm coprimeprodsq2(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(wa(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c2, cn0)), wceq(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1)), wi(wceq(co(c2, cexp, nat2), co(c0, cmul, c1)), wceq(c1, co(co(c1, cgcd, c2), cexp, nat2))))
} = {
  sylbid(wa(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c2, cn0)), wceq(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1)), wceq(co(c2, cexp, nat2), co(c0, cmul, c1)), wceq(c1, co(co(c1, cgcd, c2), cexp, nat2)), wceq(co(c2, cexp, nat2), co(c1, cmul, c0)))
  eqeq2d(co(c2, cexp, nat2), co(c0, cmul, c1), co(c1, cmul, c0), wa(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c2, cn0)), wceq(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1)))
  adantr(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c2, cn0)), wceq(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1), wceq(co(c0, cmul, c1), co(c1, cmul, c0)))
  3adant3(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c2, cn0), wceq(co(c0, cmul, c1), co(c1, cmul, c0)))
  syl2an(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wceq(co(c0, cmul, c1), co(c1, cmul, c0)), wcel(c0, cc), wcel(c1, cc))
  zcn(c0)
  nn0cn(c1)
  mulcom(c0, c1)
  syl31anc(wa(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c2, cn0)), wceq(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1)), wi(wceq(co(c2, cexp, nat2), co(c1, cmul, c0)), wceq(c1, co(co(c1, cgcd, c2), cexp, nat2))), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c2, cn0), wceq(co(co(c1, cgcd, c0), cgcd, c2), nat1))
  simpl2(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c2, cn0), wceq(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1))
  simpl1(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c2, cn0), wceq(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1))
  simpl3(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c2, cn0), wceq(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1))
  biimpa(w3a(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c2, cn0)), wceq(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1), wceq(co(co(c1, cgcd, c0), cgcd, c2), nat1))
  3adant3(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wcel(c2, cn0), wb(wceq(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1), wceq(co(co(c1, cgcd, c0), cgcd, c2), nat1)))
  sylan2(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cn0), wb(wceq(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1), wceq(co(co(c1, cgcd, c0), cgcd, c2), nat1)), wcel(c1, cz))
  nn0z(c1)
  eqeq1d(co(co(c0, cgcd, c1), cgcd, c2), nat1, co(co(c1, cgcd, c0), cgcd, c2), wa(wcel(c0, cz), wcel(c1, cz)))

  gcdcom(c0, c1)
  coprimeprodsq(c1, c0, c2)

blocks.name: oddprm
blocks.content: A prime not equal to ` 2 ` is odd. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 4-Feb-2015.) (Proof shortened by AV, 10-Jul-2022.)
blocks.origin:
thm oddprm(class c0) {

thm nnoddn2prmb(class c0) {
  ⊢ (c0 ∈(Prime \ { 2 })↔(c0 ∈ Prime ∧ ¬ 2[||]c0))
} = {
  impbii(c0 ∈(Prime \ { 2 }), (c0 ∈ Prime ∧ ¬ 2[||]c0))

  simpl(c0 ∈ Prime, ¬ 2[||]c0)

  neqned(c0, nat2, (c0 ∈ Prime ∧ ¬ 2[||]c0))

  mpbiri(c0 = 2, 2[||]c0, 2[||]2)
  z2even()
  breq2(c0, nat2, nat2, cdvds)
  nelsn(c0, nat2)
}

} = {
  rexlimivv(s0, s1, cn, cn, wrex(s2, cn, w3a(wceq(c0, co(cv(s2), cmul, co(co(cv(s1), cexp, nat2), cmin, co(cv(s0), cexp, nat2)))), wceq(c1, co(cv(s2), cmul, co(nat2, cmul, co(cv(s1), cmul, cv(s0))))), wceq(c2, co(cv(s2), cmul, co(co(cv(s1), cexp, nat2), caddc, co(cv(s0), cexp, nat2)))))), wceq(co(co(c0, cexp, nat2), caddc, co(c1, cexp, nat2)), co(c2, cexp, nat2)))

blocks.name: pythagtriplem3
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ pythagtrip . Show that ` C ` and ` B ` are relatively prime under some conditions. (Contributed by Scott Fenton, 8-Apr-2014.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 19-Apr-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm pythagtriplem3(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, cn), wcel(c2, cn)), wceq(co(co(c0, cexp, nat2), caddc, co(c1, cexp, nat2)), co(c2, cexp, nat2)), wa(wceq(co(c0, cgcd, c1), nat1), wn(wbr(nat2, cdvds, c0)))), wceq(co(c1, cgcd, c2), nat1))
} = {
  mpbid(w3a(w3a(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, cn), wcel(c2, cn)), wceq(co(co(c0, cexp, nat2), caddc, co(c1, cexp, nat2)), co(c2, cexp, nat2)), wa(wceq(co(c0, cgcd, c1), nat1), wn(wbr(nat2, cdvds, c0)))), wceq(co(c1, cgcd, c2), nat1), wceq(co(co(c1, cgcd, c2), cexp, nat2), co(nat1, cexp, nat2)))

blocks.name: pythagtriplem4

blocks.name: pythagtriplem13
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ pythagtrip . Show that ` N ` (which will eventually be closely related to the ` n ` in the final statement) is a natural. (Contributed by Scott Fenton, 17-Apr-2014.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 19-Apr-2014.)
blocks.origin:

  -| wceq(c3, co(co(cfv(csqrt, co(c2, caddc, c1)), cmin, cfv(csqrt, co(c2, cmin, c1))), cdiv, nat2))
} = {

  divcan3(c2, nat2)
}

blocks.content: Lemma for ~ pythagtrip . Introduce ` k ` and remove the relative primality requirement. (Contributed by Scott Fenton, 18-Apr-2014.) (Revised by Mario Carneiro, 19-Apr-2014.)

blocks.name: pythagtrip
blocks.content: Parameterize the Pythagorean triples. If ` A ` , ` B ` , and ` C ` are naturals, then they obey the Pythagorean triple formula iff they are parameterized by three naturals. This proof follows the Isabelle proof at ~ http://afp.sourceforge.net/entries/Fermat3_4.shtml . This is Metamath 100 proof #23. (Contributed by Scott Fenton, 19-Apr-2014.)
blocks.origin:
thm pythagtrip(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2, class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(w3a(wcel(c0, cn), wcel(c1, cn), wcel(c2, cn)), wb(wceq(co(co(c0, cexp, nat2), caddc, co(c1, cexp, nat2)), co(c2, cexp, nat2)), wrex(s0, cn, wrex(s1, cn, wrex(s2, cn, wa(wceq(cpr(c0, c1), cpr(co(cv(s2), cmul, co(co(cv(s1), cexp, nat2), cmin, co(cv(s0), cexp, nat2))), co(cv(s2), cmul, co(nat2, cmul, co(cv(s1), cmul, cv(s0)))))), wceq(c2, co(cv(s2), cmul, co(co(cv(s1), cexp, nat2), caddc, co(cv(s0), cexp, nat2))))))))))
  -| diffss(s0, s1)
  -| diffss(s0, s2)
  -| diffss(s1, s2)
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c1)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
  -| diffsc(s1, c0)
  -| diffsc(s1, c1)
  -| diffsc(s1, c2)
  -| diffsc(s2, c0)
  -| diffsc(s2, c1)
  -| diffsc(s2, c2)
} = {

blocks.name: iserodd
blocks.content: Collect the odd terms in a sequence. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 7-Apr-2015.) (Proof shortened by AV, 10-Jul-2022.)
blocks.origin:
